metadata.title: Supplementary Information for Cell membrane proteins with high N-glycosylation, high expression, and multiple interaction partners are preferred by mammalian viruses as receptors

affiliation.institution: Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences & Peking Union Medical College
Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences & Peking Union Medical College

body_text.text: The data of mammalian virus-host receptor interaction were compiled from three sources: firstly, proteins annotated with one of GO terms "virus receptor activity", "viral entry into host cell" and "receptor activity" in UniprotKB database (Bateman, et al., 2017) were collected on August 14 th , 2017, and manually checked later; secondly, part of viral receptors were directly obtained from the database of ViralZone (Masson, et al., 2013) on September 9 th , 2017; thirdly, the literature related to viral receptors (a total of 1303 papers) were downloaded from NCBI Pubmed database (Agarwala, et al., 2016) by searching "virus receptor" [TIAB] or "viral receptor"[TIAB] on August 14 th , 2017. The mammalian virus and their related host receptors were manually extracted from the literature. In combination, a database was created with 268 pairs of mammalian virus-host receptor interaction, which included 128 unique viral species or sub-species and 119 viral receptors (Table S1) .
body_text.section: Database of mammalian virus-host receptor interaction

body_text.text: The number of transmembrane alpha helix of the mammalian virus receptor was derived from the database of UniprotKB and the web server TMpred (Hofmann and Stoffel, 2017) . The location for the viral receptor was inferred from the description of "Subcellular location" for the receptor protein provided by UniProtKB, or from the GO annotations for them: the viral receptors annotated with GO terms which included the words of "cell surface" or "plasma membrane" were considered to be located in the cell membrane; those annotated with GO terms which included the words of "cytoplasm", "cytosol" or "cytoplasmic vesicle", or shown to be in the cytoplasm in UniProtKB, were considered to be located in the cytoplasm; those annotated with GO terms "nucleus" (GO:0005634) or "nucleoplasm" (GO:0005654) were considered to be located in the nuclear. The Pfam family, the N-glycosylation and O-glycosylation sites for the protein were obtained from the database of UniprotKB.
body_text.section: Analysis of structural features of viral receptors

body_text.text: For comparison, the human proteins and their related structural characteristics were obtained from the database of UniProtKB/SwissProt on November 24 th , 2017. The proteins which had at least one transmembrane alpha helix were considered as membrane proteins. The membrane proteins which were shown to be located in the cell membrane were considered as cell membrane proteins. In total, we obtained 20243 human proteins, 5187 human membrane proteins and 2208 human cell membrane proteins.
body_text.section: Analysis of structural features of viral receptors

body_text.text: The 3D structure for the viral receptor HTR2A were modeled with the help of I-TASSER (Roy, et al., 2010) based on the protein sequence of HTR2A (accession number in the database of UniProt: P28223). The best model was selected, and visualized in RasMol (version 2.7.5) (Bernstein, 2017) .
body_text.section: Analysis of structural features of viral receptors

body_text.text: The GO function and KEGG pathway enrichment analysis for the human viral receptor were conducted with functions of enrichGO() and enrichKEGG() in the package "clusterProfiler" (version 3.4.4) (Yu, et al., 2012) in R (version 3.4.2) (Team, 2016).

The human PPI network (PPIN) was constructed based on the work of Menche et al (Menche, et al., 2015) . It included a total of 13,460 human proteins that are interconnected by 141,296 interactions. Nodes in PPIN represent proteins and edges in PPIN represent PPI's. Two measures were used to analyze the importance of a protein in the human PPIN. The first is the node degree, which is defined as the number of connections the node has to other nodes in the human PPIN; the other is the node betweenness, which is defined as the number of shortest paths that pass through the node. The degree and betweenness for each protein in the PPIN were calculated with functions of degree() and betweenness() in the package "igraph" (version 1.0.0) (Csardi and Nepusz, 2006) in R (version 3.2.5). The network was displayed with Cytoscape (version 2.6.2) (Shannon, et al., 2003) .

For robustness of the results, we also conducted PPI analysis based on the human PPIs derived from the STRING database (version 10.5) (Szklarczyk, et al., 2015) . The human PPIN was built based on the PPIs with median confidence (combined score equal to or greater than 0.4). It included 710,188 PPIs and 17,487 proteins which could be mapped to NCBI gene ids. Analysis of this human PPIN showed that human virus receptor proteins had far more interaction partners and higher betweenness than other human proteins did in the human PPIN ( Figure S4A&C ), which was similar to those derived based on the human PPIN from the work of Menche et al (Menche, et al., 2015) .

To identify the homolog of the mammalian virus receptor in other mammal species, the protein sequence of each viral receptor was searched against the database of mammalian protein sequences, which were downloaded from NCBI RefSeq database (Pruitt, et al., 2012) on October 10 th , 2017, with the help of BLAST (version 2.6.0) (Altschul, et al., 1990) . Analysis showed that in the database of mammalian protein sequences, there were 108 richly-annotated mammal species which had far more protein sequences than other mammal species did (Table S4) . Therefore, only these 108 mammal species were considered in the evolutionary analysis. Based on the results of BLAST, the homolog for the viral receptor was defined as the hit with E-value small than 1E-10, coverage equal to or greater than 80% and sequence identity equal to or greater than 30%. Only the closest homolog, i.e., the best hit, in each mammal species was used for further analysis.

For measuring the sequence conservation of mammalian virus receptors, two indicators were used. The first indicator was the number of mammal species with homolog of the viral receptor in 108 mammal species. The other indicator was the average of the pairwise sequence identities between the viral receptor and its homologs in 108 mammal species. Besides, we also calculated the conservation level of amino-acid residues in virus receptors. We defined the conservation score of an amino acid site as the ratio of the dominant amino acid in the site, which is comparable among proteins. Then, we calculated the conservation scores for all amino acid sites in the mammalian virus receptors (119 receptors).

For measuring the structural conservation of mammalian virus receptors, we identified Pfam domains in mammalian virus receptors and their homologs with the help of HMMER (version 3.1b2) (Eddy, 2011) (an E-value cut-off of 10−3 was used).
For comparison, our analysis included a set of 1000 human protein sequences, which were randomly selected from the NCBI RefSeq database (Table S6) .

The expression level for human viral receptors and other human genes in 32 human tissues were derived from the Expression Atlas database (Petryszak, et al., 2016) . To reduce the influence of extreme values, the median of expression values for a gene set was used when comparing the average expression level of human viral receptors and other set of human genes in 32 human tissues.
body_text.section: Analysis of the tissue-specific expression of human viral receptors

body_text.text: All the statistical analysis was conducted in R (version 3.2.5) (R Core Team, 2016).

The wilcoxon rank-sum test was conducted with the function of wilcox.test(). Figure S1 . The mammalian viruses and their related receptors in our database. The lines between the virus and their related receptors were colored according to the group of the virus in the Baltimore classification. The names of some viral families were presented in italic. Viral names were displayed in abbreviation (see Table S1 for the full name). The host names were given for the receptor of non-human mammal

Comparing the degree of proteins in the set of human viral receptors, human cell membrane proteins, human membrane proteins and all human proteins based on the human PPI network (PPIN) derived from the STRING database (version 10.5) (Szklarczyk, et al., 2015) . The human PPIN included 710,188 PPIs and 17,487 proteins. "***", p-value < 0.001 in the Wilcoxon rank-sum test. (B) Comparing the betweenness of proteins in the set of human viral receptors, human cell membrane proteins, human membrane proteins and all human proteins based on the human PPI network derived from the work of Menche et al. "***", p-value < 0.001 in the Wilcoxon rank-sum test. (C) Comparing the betweenness of proteins in the set of human viral receptors, human cell membrane proteins, human membrane proteins and all human proteins based on the human PPI network derived from the STRING database (version 10.5). "***", p-value < 0.001 in the Wilcoxon rank-sum test. (D) Partial human PPI network derived from Menche's work. It was only composed of PPIs between human viral receptors, and included a total of 50 viral receptors and 88 PPIs (including the self-interactions (in loop)). The gene symbol for each node was presented. The node in blue refers to those with self-interactions. For clarity, the node degree or betweenness was transformed in natural logarithm. Comparing the number of species among 108 mammal species which had homologs to mammalian virus receptors (119 receptors), human virus receptors (74 receptors) and 1000 human proteins randomly selected (see Table S6 ). (E) Comparing the average pairwise sequence identities between the proteins in mammalian virus receptors (119 receptors), human virus receptors (74 receptors), 1000 human proteins randomly selected (Table S6 ) and their homologs in 108 mammal species.
body_text.section: Figure S4. Protein-protein interaction analysis of human virus receptors. (A)

FIGREF1.text: Description of mammalian virus-host receptors. (A) Host composition for the viral receptor. The numbers in parentheses refer to the number of viral receptor for the host. (B) Distribution of the number of viruses using the same viral receptor.

FIGREF2.text: Structural analysis of the mammalian virus receptors. (A)Distribution of the number of transmembrane alpha helix within a viral receptor protein for the mammalian viral receptor. (B) Top ten Pfam families observed in the mammalian viral receptor proteins. (C) Comparing O-glycosylation levels between mammal viral receptors, human viral receptors, human cell membrane proteins, human membrane proteins and all human proteins. There were no significant differences between them (p-value > 0.1 in the Wilcoxon rank-sum test).

FIGREF3.text: Conservation analysis of mammalian virus receptors. (A) Distribution of the number of mammal species with homologs to mammalian virus receptors (119 receptors) in 108 mammal species. (B) Distribution of the average pairwise sequence identities between mammalian virus receptors (119 receptors) and their homologs in mammal species. (C) Distribution of conservation scores of amino acid sites in mammalian virus receptors (119 receptors). The Y-axis refers to the ratio of amino acid sites within the conservation score intervals in mammalian virus receptors. (D)
